Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor How do I now teach myself to not wake up in the middle of the night wondering and pondering "what if?" and to not wander off during the day into a mental fog of "what if?" How do I live with what appears to be a future of uncertainty and ambiguity regarding prostate health and prognosis? Interesting dilemma. I guess, that, simply put, life itself is ultimately out of our control. We did not choose our conception, our DNA, our birth and innumerable other factors. All of that was done for us. Would we have objected had we known? Our culture obsesses with the future - one which may never arrive. Our end is coming and there is no accurate way of knowing or even of predicting. We are given 24 hours at a time, yet we live in the instant moment, never being entirely certain of what the next moment will bring. Personally, before tomorrow can be a problem, I have to wake up tomorrow.
Posts.Signature: 05/08-07/08 Tumor appears behind left ear. Followed by serial medical incompetence on the parts of PCP, veteran oncologist and pathologist (misdiagnosis via non-diagnosis). Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: How do I learn to be patient/less stressed while waiting months for diagnostic info?

Posts.Content: We like control. We like knowledge. We like certainty. Unfortunately, that is often lacking or beyond our grasp in this life. The serenity prayer as used by AA gives wise counsel. If you are not a "higher being" oriented person, then Mindfulness offers a version of the same thing.

Posts.Title: How do I learn to be patient/less stressed while waiting months for diagnostic info?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 po18guy: You, more than anyone, know the ins and outs related to trials. The OP talks of difficulty with ADT but are there no conventional treatments available prior to going to trials? Aren't trials normally utilized after all other mainstream methodologies have been tried? Jim (Forgive my wordiness - prednisone at work) As with everything else cancer, it all depends. If a patient has co-morbidities that limit standard therapy, then other routes such as clinical trials must be sought out. Trials seek both to reduce toxicity and increase effectiveness. Participating in a clinical trial is both a selfish and selfless thing to do at the same time. Of course the patient wants a benefit, a "cure", but trials also advance the frontiers of science and allow the patient to receive advanced drugs 2-3 years ahead of the general public. There is not a drug on the market that has not been subjected to the clinical trial process - which is good, as the trial produces data relating to safety, efficacy, and applicability to various sub-types of cancer. With trials, timing can be everything. It might be that a promising trial opens up just as standard treatments fail, or the disease relapses. Such a trial saved my life, and it is edifying to read of others now receiving the drug in its approved form. Contrast this to Germany, where with certain cancers you are automatically sent to clinical trial - and for that reason, there are larger cohorts there. Regarding standard therapy, there is also the patient preference of maintaining his current lifestyle/sexual function as closely as possible - the risk being that this can lead to a less effective therapy. Treatments with a known efficacy and limited ("acceptable") toxicity or side effects are normally the first choice. However, some patients simply won't have it. Doctor/patient communication is vital, and while a certain treatment might be the best, doctor cannot always convince the patient to receive it. I come from a tiny cubby hole in the lymphoma world, and I do not hear all that much about ADT in prostate. There must be a reason that the OP's friend chose that route - disease location/grade/spread etc. We also do not know if that was primary, consolidation or salvage therapy in his case. As the OP fills in the missing information, it may become clearer why the ADT was chosen, or if that was even the primary therapy. Chemotherapy lives forever under the burden of its bad reputation, as well as rumors and plain old myths. We see those questions regularly.

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear of this, but good that you are aware of it and are addressing it. I have not had PCa, but a possibility in your case is Trazodone. It is a well proven anti-anxiety/anti-depressant drug that also helps with insomnia. It was prescribed to me to help me sleep, as I have been on high dose steroids for over two years. Anyway, here's something else: it helps with urine flow and in some cases, produces a Cialis-like effect. Could be a two-fer. It is a "clean drug" meaining that it has a good toxicity profile, and is available generic, so the cost is low. Worth asking about.

Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer with liver mets, need a PD-1 trial...

Posts.Content: A word of explanation: My journey, as with all, has been absolutely unique. In that regard, my experience has been that I was paired with a hematologist who not only did not mind being challenged, actually invited it, rising to the occasion. It is fact that the majority of doctors do not like to be challenged, asked questions for which they may not have an immediate answer, or being directed toward a certain therapy. Some of the doctors with whom I have consulted visibly bristled at the idea of a pro-active patient. One needs to have a good feel for their doctor - since it is doctor's practice and personality - but our life that is involved. Many (not all) are unaccustomed to an informed patient, and anything perceived as a challenge my be of-putting. I was blessed in that regard, inasmuch as I have been actively involved, even encouraged to be, in the decision-making process. His operative mode is that he cannot know everything, and all paths are worth investigating.

Posts.Title: Anti-Depressants

Posts.Content: This is brand new, and as of June 16th, is not yet recruiting. The screening therefore seems to be a preparatory step for recruitment. Unless someone out here happened to be in the few that participated in the early phase I trial, there will be no one with experience. I note that the sample is distinctly small, at 30 patients. Normally, for truly valid results, a much larger cohort is sought, especially for such a common cancer. Based on the Nasdaq promotional piece, I would guess that TYME is scrambling for funding to conduct a larger phase III trial. The phase 1b-2 studies primarily the maximum dosage that the human body will tolerate, with efficacy a lesser consideration. As with all clinical trials, it requires dedication to participation in research, regardless of the benefit. By their very nature, clinical trials are a leap of faith, and there is very little knowledge of short-term effects and absolutely none of long-term effects. That data will be gained from patients as the trial progresses.

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 po18guy: You, more than anyone, know the ins and outs related to trials. The OP talks of difficulty with ADT but are there no conventional treatments available prior to going to trials? Aren't trials normally utilized after all other mainstream methodologies have been tried? Jim (Forgive my wordiness - prednisone at work) As with everything else cancer, it all depends. If a patient has co-morbidities that limit standard therapy, then other routes such as clinical trials must be sought out. Trials seek both to reduce toxicity and increase effectiveness. Participating in a clinical trial is both a selfish and selfless thing to do at the same time. Of course the patient wants a benefit, a "cure", but trials also advance the frontiers of science and allow the patient to receive advanced drugs 2-3 years ahead of the general public. There is not a drug on the market that has not been subjected to the clinical trial process - which is good, as the trial produces data relating to safety, efficacy, and applicability to various sub-types of cancer. With trials, timing can be everything. It might be that a promising trial opens up just as standard treatments fail, or the disease relapses. Such a trial saved my life, and it is edifying to read of others now receiving the drug in its approved form. Contrast this to Germany, where with certain cancers you are automatically sent to clinical trial - and for that reason, there are larger cohorts there. Regarding standard therapy, there is also the patient preference of maintaining his current lifestyle/sexual function as closely as possible - the risk being that this can lead to a less effective therapy. Treatments with a known efficacy and limited ("acceptable") toxicity or side effects are normally the first choice. However, some patients simply won't have it. Doctor/patient communication is vital, and while a certain treatment might be the best, doctor cannot always convince the patient to receive it. I come from a tiny cubby hole in the lymphoma world, and I do not hear all that much about ADT in prostate. There must be a reason that the OP's friend chose that route - disease location/grade/spread etc. We also do not know if that was primary, consolidation or salvage therapy in his case. As the OP fills in the missing information, it may become clearer why the ADT was chosen, or if that was even the primary therapy. Chemotherapy lives forever under the burden of its bad reputation, as well as rumors and plain old myths. We see those questions regularly.

DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: This is brand new, and as of June 16th, is not yet recruiting. The screening therefore seems to be a preparatory step for recruitment. Unless someone out here happened to be in the few that participated in the early phase I trial, there will be no one with experience. I note that the sample is distinctly small, at 30 patients. Normally, for truly valid results, a much larger cohort is sought, especially for such a common cancer. Based on the Nasdaq promotional piece, I would guess that TYME is scrambling for funding to conduct a larger phase III trial. The phase 1b-2 studies primarily the maximum dosage that the human body will tolerate, with efficacy a lesser consideration. As with all clinical trials, it requires dedication to participation in research, regardless of the benefit. By their very nature, clinical trials are a leap of faith, and there is very little knowledge of short-term effects and absolutely none of long-term effects. That data will be gained from patients as the trial progresses.

Posts.Title: How do I learn to be patient/less stressed while waiting months for diagnostic info?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor How do I now teach myself to not wake up in the middle of the night wondering and pondering "what if?" and to not wander off during the day into a mental fog of "what if?" How do I live with what appears to be a future of uncertainty and ambiguity regarding prostate health and prognosis? Interesting dilemma. I guess, that, simply put, life itself is ultimately out of our control. We did not choose our conception, our DNA, our birth and innumerable other factors. All of that was done for us. Would we have objected had we known? Our culture obsesses with the future - one which may never arrive. Our end is coming and there is no accurate way of knowing or even of predicting. We are given 24 hours at a time, yet we live in the instant moment, never being entirely certain of what the next moment will bring. Personally, before tomorrow can be a problem, I have to wake up tomorrow.

Posts.Content: Sorry to welcome you here under these circumstances. I have moved your post to the prostate cancer forum, where it will receive more attention. As well, here is a link to prostate caner clinical trials: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/re...&Search=Search
Posts.Signature: 05/08-07/08 Tumor appears behind left ear. Followed by serial medical incompetence on the parts of PCP, veteran oncologist and pathologist (misdiagnosis via non-diagnosis). Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer with liver mets, need a PD-1 trial...

Posts.Content: A word of explanation: My journey, as with all, has been absolutely unique. In that regard, my experience has been that I was paired with a hematologist who not only did not mind being challenged, actually invited it, rising to the occasion. It is fact that the majority of doctors do not like to be challenged, asked questions for which they may not have an immediate answer, or being directed toward a certain therapy. Some of the doctors with whom I have consulted visibly bristled at the idea of a pro-active patient. One needs to have a good feel for their doctor - since it is doctor's practice and personality - but our life that is involved. Many (not all) are unaccustomed to an informed patient, and anything perceived as a challenge my be of-putting. I was blessed in that regard, inasmuch as I have been actively involved, even encouraged to be, in the decision-making process. His operative mode is that he cannot know everything, and all paths are worth investigating.

Posts.Title: Anti-Depressants

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 po18guy: You, more than anyone, know the ins and outs related to trials. The OP talks of difficulty with ADT but are there no conventional treatments available prior to going to trials? Aren't trials normally utilized after all other mainstream methodologies have been tried? Jim (Forgive my wordiness - prednisone at work) As with everything else cancer, it all depends. If a patient has co-morbidities that limit standard therapy, then other routes such as clinical trials must be sought out. Trials seek both to reduce toxicity and increase effectiveness. Participating in a clinical trial is both a selfish and selfless thing to do at the same time. Of course the patient wants a benefit, a "cure", but trials also advance the frontiers of science and allow the patient to receive advanced drugs 2-3 years ahead of the general public. There is not a drug on the market that has not been subjected to the clinical trial process - which is good, as the trial produces data relating to safety, efficacy, and applicability to various sub-types of cancer. With trials, timing can be everything. It might be that a promising trial opens up just as standard treatments fail, or the disease relapses. Such a trial saved my life, and it is edifying to read of others now receiving the drug in its approved form. Contrast this to Germany, where with certain cancers you are automatically sent to clinical trial - and for that reason, there are larger cohorts there. Regarding standard therapy, there is also the patient preference of maintaining his current lifestyle/sexual function as closely as possible - the risk being that this can lead to a less effective therapy. Treatments with a known efficacy and limited ("acceptable") toxicity or side effects are normally the first choice. However, some patients simply won't have it. Doctor/patient communication is vital, and while a certain treatment might be the best, doctor cannot always convince the patient to receive it. I come from a tiny cubby hole in the lymphoma world, and I do not hear all that much about ADT in prostate. There must be a reason that the OP's friend chose that route - disease location/grade/spread etc. We also do not know if that was primary, consolidation or salvage therapy in his case. As the OP fills in the missing information, it may become clearer why the ADT was chosen, or if that was even the primary therapy. Chemotherapy lives forever under the burden of its bad reputation, as well as rumors and plain old myths. We see those questions regularly.

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: This is brand new, and as of June 16th, is not yet recruiting. The screening therefore seems to be a preparatory step for recruitment. Unless someone out here happened to be in the few that participated in the early phase I trial, there will be no one with experience. I note that the sample is distinctly small, at 30 patients. Normally, for truly valid results, a much larger cohort is sought, especially for such a common cancer. Based on the Nasdaq promotional piece, I would guess that TYME is scrambling for funding to conduct a larger phase III trial. The phase 1b-2 studies primarily the maximum dosage that the human body will tolerate, with efficacy a lesser consideration. As with all clinical trials, it requires dedication to participation in research, regardless of the benefit. By their very nature, clinical trials are a leap of faith, and there is very little knowledge of short-term effects and absolutely none of long-term effects. That data will be gained from patients as the trial progresses.

Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear of this, but good that you are aware of it and are addressing it. I have not had PCa, but a possibility in your case is Trazodone. It is a well proven anti-anxiety/anti-depressant drug that also helps with insomnia. It was prescribed to me to help me sleep, as I have been on high dose steroids for over two years. Anyway, here's something else: it helps with urine flow and in some cases, produces a Cialis-like effect. Could be a two-fer. It is a "clean drug" meaining that it has a good toxicity profile, and is available generic, so the cost is low. Worth asking about.

Posts.Title: Anti-Depressants

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 po18guy: You, more than anyone, know the ins and outs related to trials. The OP talks of difficulty with ADT but are there no conventional treatments available prior to going to trials? Aren't trials normally utilized after all other mainstream methodologies have been tried? Jim (Forgive my wordiness - prednisone at work) As with everything else cancer, it all depends. If a patient has co-morbidities that limit standard therapy, then other routes such as clinical trials must be sought out. Trials seek both to reduce toxicity and increase effectiveness. Participating in a clinical trial is both a selfish and selfless thing to do at the same time. Of course the patient wants a benefit, a "cure", but trials also advance the frontiers of science and allow the patient to receive advanced drugs 2-3 years ahead of the general public. There is not a drug on the market that has not been subjected to the clinical trial process - which is good, as the trial produces data relating to safety, efficacy, and applicability to various sub-types of cancer. With trials, timing can be everything. It might be that a promising trial opens up just as standard treatments fail, or the disease relapses. Such a trial saved my life, and it is edifying to read of others now receiving the drug in its approved form. Contrast this to Germany, where with certain cancers you are automatically sent to clinical trial - and for that reason, there are larger cohorts there. Regarding standard therapy, there is also the patient preference of maintaining his current lifestyle/sexual function as closely as possible - the risk being that this can lead to a less effective therapy. Treatments with a known efficacy and limited ("acceptable") toxicity or side effects are normally the first choice. However, some patients simply won't have it. Doctor/patient communication is vital, and while a certain treatment might be the best, doctor cannot always convince the patient to receive it. I come from a tiny cubby hole in the lymphoma world, and I do not hear all that much about ADT in prostate. There must be a reason that the OP's friend chose that route - disease location/grade/spread etc. We also do not know if that was primary, consolidation or salvage therapy in his case. As the OP fills in the missing information, it may become clearer why the ADT was chosen, or if that was even the primary therapy. Chemotherapy lives forever under the burden of its bad reputation, as well as rumors and plain old myths. We see those questions regularly.

Posts.Title: False positive?

Posts.Content: PSA levels are adjusted for age. According to this article, your level is fine for your age. Remember that a percentage of prostate cancer occurs in men with "normal" PSA levels. PSA, by itself, does not determine anything. It is a potential indicator. Many men with very high PSAs never develop prostate cancer. Is there some reason, other than your father's cancer, why you have been monitored for so long?

Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: Prostate PSA Level Concern

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear of this. An awful lot depends on your dad's general health. Remember that any chemotherapy given will be carefully adjusted to account for his weight, age and general health. As well, if one drug does not work, there are always alternatives. Since 2008, I have received a total of seventeen chemotherapy drugs and I am still here - it was for a different cancer, however. If I was in his situation, I would search for a clinical trial, as they offer promising new cutting-edge drugs which are not available to the public. I participated in two trials. Medical science is advanced by patients being wiling to participate in clinical trials. If the trial is not effective, he can always withdraw from it and revert back to the original plan. Search for trials here: www.clinicaltrials.gov Just type "Metastatic Prostate Cancer" into the search box and numerous possibilities will come up.

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy questions

Posts.Content: OK I was just trying to flush out any potential anxiety issues. High PSA may be consistent with, but is not per se, predictive or diagnostic of cancer. Just something to watch - which you and doctor are.

Posts.Title: Dizziness

Posts.Content: They are a private, profit-driven concern. Thus, it appears that one must have the financial reserves and appropriate insurance before they will accept you as a patient. I would risk such a center only if I had a very common cancer, with no complications, and for which treatment was very well defined. I highly recommend any of the comprehensive cancer centers which are affiliated with the National Cancer Institute. Find the nearest facility here: http://www.cancer.gov/researchandfun.../cancercenters

Posts.Title: Cancer Treament Centers of America

Posts.Content: Time for a lot of reflection, and being thankful for that which we have, and that which we have had. Since the future is guaranteed to exactly no one, we find things in the 'right here and now' to appreciate. No matter the cancer, I look at sick children, paralyzed people of all ages, disabilities of every type - I cannot feel as though I have been cheated. I had about a 50/50 chance of seeing my first Christmas after diagnosis. Two months ago, a doctor told me that I probably had a 0.5% chance of being here today. This will be my tenth Christmas after diagnosis. We have much to be thankful for.

Posts.Title: First holiday season with cancer.

Posts.Content: Both of you are too kind. I find that it is easier to appear strong than to actually be strong. Each day we begin anew and try to avoid failure early on!

BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas Everyone!

Posts.Content: Very sorry to hear of this issue, Allen. I would be consoled by the obvious evidence of the UTI, as well as its response to antis. I don't think that any malignancy would behave like that. But, a different antibiotic might be needed as we are breeding smarter bacteria as this world goes on. Right now, worry is sapping your resolve. I would say that of course you have another fight in you - you receive the strength if you ask for it, but you may not have to fight at all. Think of it this way: if you fell into a river, would you just sink to the bottom, or would you struggle back to the surface? I do not see cancer as bigger than life. Rather, I see it as part of life, and one which poses a certain threat, but also a challenge. Yes, there are days when I'm just tired of it all, but that feeling passes and I am convinced that I have another fight left in me. Looking around at those I love, how could I give up?

Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Sorry to welcome you here under these circumstances. I moved your post to the prostate cancer forum, where it ill receive much more attention. What does your father think of all this? That is important, as it remains his life. If he wants help, then I would gather as much of his medical history as possible and contact a prostate cancer specialist at a National Cancer Institute designated cancer center for advice. In that link, you may find such a center that is closest to you. All the best to you and your dad.

Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Your own urologist, who is well familiar with you, is only a phone call away.
Posts.Signature: 05/08-07/08 Tumor appears behind left ear. Followed by serial medical incompetence on the parts of PCP, veteran oncologist and pathologist (misdiagnosis via non-diagnosis). Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: Any Urologists on this forum??

Posts.Content: This is a prescription only drug. You will simply have to search pharmacy availability.
Posts.Title: Can't find drugs

Posts.Content: I did not have PC, but did have enormous ankles during treatment. I used compression hosiery which is available at drug stores. A pain to put on, but they essentially squeeze the fluid out and back up the legs. Plus, I slept on the floor with my legs raised on a chair. Can be uncomfortable, but you wonder how far that skin can stretch.

Posts.Title: Lymphederma

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dead Man Walking Legally, this is a dietary supplement, which means you can make ZERO claims for efficacy, or whether it evens works at all.. From the NIH link the study is listed as Preclinical, which appears to mean that they are trying to figure out how this stuff works chemically, if indeed it does work. If you're talking about this as an investment from a financial standpoint, it's way, way. way too early to know anything at all. What he said. Miracle remedies, cures and you-name-it come along regularly. Nothing wrong with eating broccoli - I prefer it steamed with butter - but I don't expect it to do anything other than taste good. Much of what we discuss, our children will benefit from, if there is any benefit to be derived from it.

Posts.Title: Broccoli Seed Extract

Posts.Content: Remember that the standard for radiologists is the perfect human body as depicted on the wall chart in every doctor's office. Any deviation, however slight, causes their alarm to sound. I have had them caution me about CT focal points on my prostate, only to have the all clear sounded from both my primary physician as well as from a colorectal surgeon. As well, they always mention the hyperplasia, even though it is the rare man indeed who does not experience this past age 50 or so. But, prostate cancer is one of the "big four" cancers and so I would guess that it merits the attention. I do not recall a single mention of my thymus in CT reports, even though it has atrophied substantially (as it does in all post-pubescent humans). Not much thymus cancer to worry about, I suppose.

Posts.Title: Broccoli Seed Extract

Posts.Content: Not a PC patient, but from your signature: "Pathology: Bladder neck (microscopic) and seminal vesicle involvement + large volume of PC, clear margins" If this was renal cell carcinoma, or pancreatic cancer, would proton beam radiation then sound reasonable? Considering that the threshold of detection is something on the order of one million cancer cells, scanning, DREs and each and every other method of detection can miss a whole lot of cancer. You have personal experience, hopes and desires which may conflict with the effects of treatment. I would give much credence to the opinions of those who encounter this daily as part of their career - and who know the long-term results.

Posts.Title: Anyone undergo radiation with a 0.01 PSA?

Posts.Content: Not a PC patient, but from your signature: "Pathology: Bladder neck (microscopic) and seminal vesicle involvement + large volume of PC, clear margins" If this was renal cell carcinoma, or pancreatic cancer, would proton beam radiation then sound reasonable? Considering that the threshold of detection is something on the order of one million cancer cells, scanning, DREs and each and every other method of detection can miss a whole lot of cancer. You have personal experience, hopes and desires which may conflict with the effects of treatment. I would give much credence to the opinions of those who encounter this daily as part of their career - and who know the long-term results.

Posts.Content: Here are the two National Cancer Institute designated cancer centers in Chicago. Both are comprehensive centers and should offer the, um, 'cutting edge' treatments, so to speak. Personally, I would never go local again, unless there was no option. Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center Northwestern University Chicago, Illinois Comprehensive Cancer Center Leonidas C. Platanias, M.D., Ph.D. Director 303 East Superior Street Chicago, Illinois 60611 Main: (312) 695-0990 Appointments: 1-866-587-4322 (1-866-LURIE-CC) The University of Chicago Comprehensive Cancer Center Chicago, Illinois Comprehensive Cancer Center Michelle M. Le Beau, Ph.D. Director 5841 South Maryland Avenue MC1140 Chicago, Illinois 60637 Pediatric Appointments: (773) 702-6808 Adult Appointments: 1-855-702-8222

BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: NW Indiana Robotic RP recommendation

Posts.Content: Are his blood counts low? If so, the spots could be petechiae, which is related to blood issues. Doctor would likely know, based on recent blood work.

Posts.Title: Red spots showing up on his skin

Posts.Content: Four one-thousandths of one percent. Think about how low that is. Hardly measurable - fairly close to the threshold of detectability. And, those results only have meaning if they were done using the same protocol at the same laboratory. For perspective, due to BPH (yes, the prostate is still there) my PSA was just checked at age 65 and it is 100 times what your dad's is. I don't even think about it. However, your posts have a very unifying theme: anxiety over all of this. Lots of anxiety, reviewing the wording you have used and the effects all of this has had on you. You say that you see fear in dad. I mean this absolutely honestly: I think he is, in part, reflecting your fear. If you are even a part-time caregiver, what are you doing for yourself? Don't let it go on to the point at which you go thud on the floor and spend an overnighter in hospital, as DW did a few years ago. Get some help with that anxiety, whether it be counseling, medication or some other means. I mean this most sincerely.

Posts.Title: can't help but panic

Posts.Content: I would go to Moffitt. If not for treatment, at least for a review of your diagnosis and treatment options. Moffitt is world-class, employs the best and brightest, and is the only National Cancer Institute designated comprehensive cancer center in Florida. Even though a one hour drive up I-75 for you, I face an almost identical drive in Seattle (worse traffic than L.A.). I originally objected to the drive, but have made that trip hundreds of times since 2008 and am alive to tell about it.

Posts.Title: RT. Providers in Sarasota Florida-?

Posts.Content: Best not to get hung up on PSA - far too many variables. CA19-9 is somewhat the same, as is LDH and so many other measures. I mean, we have folks who stress over a .01 difference in testing! What is needed is TSA (no not that agency) - a tumor specific antigen.

Posts.Title: PSA Testing Not Recommended for Prostate Cancer Screening

Posts.Content: No doubt that PSA plays a crucial part. But the almost fanatical scrutiny that we see being applied to, for but one example, a .01 difference in testing - means that: 1) there needs to be a lot more education about what those tests mean (and do not mean), 2) it must be the same test protocol by the same lab and, 3) .01 AYKM? Next to undetectable and within standard deviation. There is no point for men to stress or obsess over tiny increments. Whole numbers being quite another thing. I will reserve comment on what this tells us about men and their prioritization of sexual function, aside from cancer. My jaundiced eye reminds me that men are constantly (and rightly) accused of not being communicative. But, just let them suspect cancer "down there" and they won't shut up! Man to man here, but also slightly tongue-in-cheek.
Posts.Title: PSA Testing Not Recommended for Prostate Cancer Screening

Posts.Content: It's daft? In the British case, I detect the faint aroma of cost containment. Particularly since 718,000 men is a whole lot of testing, since NHS funds and services are limited, and since the British population is aging.

Posts.Title: PSA Testing Not Recommended for Prostate Cancer Screening

Posts.Content: OK, so here's something that is relatively cheap, but must be obtained with doctor's permission and prescription. It is designed to handle the anxiety which often accompanies BPH/Pca, the depression that can creep in with dysfunction or diagnosis, can improve urine stream and has, in some cases, the "blue pill" effect. It also helps produce sleep for those who are suffering from insomnia. The old-line drug Trazodone. My Fred Hutch hematologist calls it a "clean drug" with low/no addictive traits, and no real deficits from stopping it. It is generic, so generally affordable. Some have to adjust dosing until the desired effect is arrived at. Worth at least asking about.

Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. Posts.Content: Are his blood counts low? If so, the spots could be petechiae, which is related to blood issues. Doctor would likely know, based on recent blood work.

Posts.Title: Red spots showing up on his skin

Posts.Content: This will devolve into politics, as single-payer is a political concept. I am not big on any plan, no matter how well intended, that reduces or eliminates competition. Case in point: Before retirement, the single payer system that I was under had 90 days to make decisions on surgeries. A herniated disc had rendered me unable to work, so I went on disability. It was impinging on my sciatic nerve, rendering me pretty much immobile. I was sleeping on the floor with my legs elevated on a footstool or sofa. I received the decision on day 89. My case worker had 240+ cases on her desk and was seriously considering returning to her native Croatia. Second case in point: In 2012, I interviewed with Lymphoma Canada about their petition to Parliament seeking the provision of the drug Romidepsin by HealthCanada. I do not know when or if it was made available, but I was receiving it in 2009. That is a long wait for someone with an aggressive lymphoma. Third case in point: Yesterday I received another email from Lymphoma Canada regarding their petition to HealthCanada (pan-Canadian Oncology Drug Review) requesting that Keytruda (Pembrolizumab) be approved for Hodgkin's Lymphoma in Canada. The drug has been available in the US since 2015. Canadian approval would most likely be in 2018. That is a long time to wait for someone with refractory or relapsed Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Single payer means government. That means politically motivated budgets. Government provides two things, often in equal amounts: services and excuses.

Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.

NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
