Posts.Title: Some advice

Posts.Content: These are life-defining moments. You have come to the right place for support. Although you may feel alone, you are certainly not. If support you want, support you will get! And a lot of hope is included. Read some of the case histories here as noted in the members' signatures. I don't think that any of them would consider themselves a hero - only an ordinary guy in an extraordinary situation.
Posts.Signature: 05/08-07/08 Tumor appears behind left ear. Followed by serial medical incompetence on the parts of PCP, veteran oncologist and pathologist (misdiagnosis via non-diagnosis). Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: oh life sucks

Posts.Content: Conspiracy theorists are everywhere, from the Kennedy Assassination to black helicopters to gas prices. To indulge oneself in such is to embrace the relentlessly negative - you clearly see this. Nothing but bitterness comes from it. Ask you wife how green juice cures any cancer. Buy her a copy of The Emperor Of All Maladies which is a "biography" of cancer - since it is a living entity. Look at the effort, blood sweat and tears that have gone into the fight. To allege that all of this is a massive cover-up is completely unrealistic, if not immature or frankly, somewhat paranoid. We are incredibly complex creatures - by far the most complex and least understood on this planet. We possess this unrealistic desire for a perfect life and the dichotomy that we observe in reality can cause stress, anger and bitterness as life seems to be a cruel joke. Based on my world view, I have embraced my suffering, and am seeking to actually enjoy it, as for me, it has meaning beyond the realm of this earth. Our ability to deal with this is heavily dependent upon what we believe or do not believe. Here is a doctor/researcher oriented video on the difficulties of T-Cell Lymphomas. Give it a brief watch and maybe ask her to watch with you. Look at the extreme depth of knowledge and the desire to control or eliminate these rare lymphomas. The jargon is very technical, but shows the profound efforts made by medical science in the effort to spare human life. These researchers hate cancer and live in the micro-cellular world in man's best attempt to eradicate it.

Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Thanks, but first off I gotta say (and I'm sure you'll fix it) the video link is wrong... the text is correct if you copy and paste, but clicking on the link brings up a reply window. Interesting video. I enjoyed watching it as I have a deep appreciation for the seriousness and difficulty of the fight against cancer. I'm afraid if I show it to my wife the best I can hope is that it might make her feel fortunate to not have T-cell lymphoma. Worst case, well, she is one who feels that everything can be remedied with herbs and prayers, diet and exercise, essential oils, Reiki... I've seen it all. I have ordered the book and hope (and pray) that she will read it and maybe take it to heart. It says there is a Ken Burns documentary... I am slightly dyslexic and choose audio books if possible (it takes me forever to compose a post or reply here). Thanks for the reply and the links. I'm trying to work thru this. Odd forum quirk! I embedded the link and it works now. As to the video, there are others that apply to every kind of cancer - not just lymphomas. I hope that the book will show her that cancer is as old as mankind - it details 3000 year old mummies in the Peruvian high plains that were found to have died of various tumors! A couple of points: 1) a 100% organic paleo diet did not prevent cancer, and 2) the use of natural herbs and other remedies did not cure it. As to "natural remedies" and "alternative" treatments, my dad flew to Mexico and received Laetrile in 1979. He died at least as quickly as he would have otherwise, and probably more quickly since he had to delay/interrupt standard therapy to do that. www.quackwatch.com is an excellent resource that debunks all of the hucksters out there who want your money in exchange for the false hope of a "cure." There are no cures and I see no herbal or natural medicine survivors on Dr. Phil or any other show. I think her detour into conspiracy theories may be a defense mechanism which is her way of dealing with her own mortality. She strongly desires to triumph over her disease, and sees that so many other areas of human activity have been mastered. Thus, a cure must exist; someone must know it, but for some inexplicable reason, she cannot have it! Well, billionaire Paul Allen (ex Microsoft) has now had both Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, and no one would "sell" him the cure! Ditto for an endless litany of famous and ber-rich celebs. As to natural cures, Steve Jobs had pancreatic cancer of a less aggressive type. He delayed treatment for months as he sought the alternative/new age treatment. From the Wiki: "Despite his diagnosis, Jobs resisted his doctors' recommendations for medical intervention for nine months, instead relying on a pseudo-medicine diet to try natural healing to thwart the disease. According to Harvard researcher Ramzi Amri, his choice of alternative treatment "led to an unnecessarily early death" My hematologist states that, of all medical research and the trillions of dollars spent, the most common killers such as heart disease, diabetes, cancer and many other more common illnesses (the common cold!) have not been cured. Only infection has been controlled. My impression is that you wife is on a psychological as much as a medical journey, and is not considering the caretaker - you - and the stress and burnout you are suffering. When we marry, we seem to hear only the "better", "richer" and "health" and not the "worse", "poorer" and "sickness" in our vows. It might be shock therapy, but she should read this thread.

Posts.Title: Some advice

I hope that the book will show her that cancer is as old as mankind - it details 3000 year old mummies in the Peruvian high plains that were found to have died of various tumors! A couple of points: 1) a 100% organic paleo diet did not prevent cancer, and 2) the use of natural herbs and other remedies did not cure it. As to "natural remedies" and "alternative" treatments, my dad flew to Mexico and received Laetrile in 1979. He died at least as quickly as he would have otherwise, and probably more quickly since he had to delay/interrupt standard therapy to do that. www.quackwatch.com is an excellent resource that debunks all of the hucksters out there who want your money in exchange for the false hope of a "cure." There are no cures and I see no herbal or natural medicine survivors on Dr. Phil or any other show. I think her detour into conspiracy theories may be a defense mechanism which is her way of dealing with her own mortality. She strongly desires to triumph over her disease, and sees that so many other areas of human activity have been mastered. Thus, a cure must exist; someone must know it, but for some inexplicable reason, she cannot have it! Well, billionaire Paul Allen (ex Microsoft) has now had both Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, and no one would "sell" him the cure! Ditto for an endless litany of famous and ber-rich celebs. As to natural cures, Steve Jobs had pancreatic cancer of a less aggressive type. He delayed treatment for months as he sought the alternative/new age treatment. From the Wiki: "Despite his diagnosis, Jobs resisted his doctors' recommendations for medical intervention for nine months, instead relying on a pseudo-medicine diet to try natural healing to thwart the disease. According to Harvard researcher Ramzi Amri, his choice of alternative treatment "led to an unnecessarily early death" My hematologist states that, of all medical research and the trillions of dollars spent, the most common killers such as heart disease, diabetes, cancer and many other more common illnesses (the common cold!) have not been cured. Only infection has been controlled. My impression is that you wife is on a psychological as much as a medical journey, and is not considering the caretaker - you - and the stress and burnout you are suffering. When we marry, we seem to hear only the "better", "richer" and "health" and not the "worse", "poorer" and "sickness" in our vows. It might be shock therapy, but she should read this thread.
Posts.Signature: 05/08-07/08 Tumor appears behind left ear. Followed by serial medical incompetence on the parts of PCP, veteran oncologist and pathologist (misdiagnosis via non-diagnosis). Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Conspiracy theorists are everywhere, from the Kennedy Assassination to black helicopters to gas prices. To indulge oneself in such is to embrace the relentlessly negative - you clearly see this. Nothing but bitterness comes from it. Ask you wife how green juice cures any cancer. Buy her a copy of The Emperor Of All Maladies which is a "biography" of cancer - since it is a living entity. Look at the effort, blood sweat and tears that have gone into the fight. To allege that all of this is a massive cover-up is completely unrealistic, if not immature or frankly, somewhat paranoid. We are incredibly complex creatures - by far the most complex and least understood on this planet. We possess this unrealistic desire for a perfect life and the dichotomy that we observe in reality can cause stress, anger and bitterness as life seems to be a cruel joke. Based on my world view, I have embraced my suffering, and am seeking to actually enjoy it, as for me, it has meaning beyond the realm of this earth. Our ability to deal with this is heavily dependent upon what we believe or do not believe. Here is a doctor/researcher oriented video on the difficulties of T-Cell Lymphomas. Give it a brief watch and maybe ask her to watch with you. Look at the extreme depth of knowledge and the desire to control or eliminate these rare lymphomas. The jargon is very technical, but shows the profound efforts made by medical science in the effort to spare human life. These researchers hate cancer and live in the micro-cellular world in man's best attempt to eradicate it.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Thanks, but first off I gotta say (and I'm sure you'll fix it) the video link is wrong... the text is correct if you copy and paste, but clicking on the link brings up a reply window. Interesting video. I enjoyed watching it as I have a deep appreciation for the seriousness and difficulty of the fight against cancer. I'm afraid if I show it to my wife the best I can hope is that it might make her feel fortunate to not have T-cell lymphoma. Worst case, well, she is one who feels that everything can be remedied with herbs and prayers, diet and exercise, essential oils, Reiki... I've seen it all. I have ordered the book and hope (and pray) that she will read it and maybe take it to heart. It says there is a Ken Burns documentary... I am slightly dyslexic and choose audio books if possible (it takes me forever to compose a post or reply here). Thanks for the reply and the links. I'm trying to work thru this. Odd forum quirk! I embedded the link and it works now. As to the video, there are others that apply to every kind of cancer - not just lymphomas. I hope that the book will show her that cancer is as old as mankind - it details 3000 year old mummies in the Peruvian high plains that were found to have died of various tumors! A couple of points: 1) a 100% organic paleo diet did not prevent cancer, and 2) the use of natural herbs and other remedies did not cure it. Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 I have eaten lots almonds daily of for over 10 years, no luck there. Point #1: For "big pharma" or any other real or imagined organization to attempt to copy, emulate or otherwise synthesize any natural substance is impractical if not impossible. First the cost would be the typical 2-5 billion dollars. Secondly, it would need to undergo the trials process. Who would willingly invest billions in a substance whose efficacy is unknown and is available in natural form? Point #2: I note here that you are alive - which bears out the study results. Remember that it pertained to survival and not prevention. Once diagnosed, I would be delighted in the news that a very common food would quite likely assist in survival. Point #3: You must be alive to have complaints.

BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: Does curcumin reduce inflammation?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 I have eaten lots almonds daily of for over 10 years, no luck there. Point #1: For "big pharma" or any other real or imagined organization to attempt to copy, emulate or otherwise synthesize any natural substance is impractical if not impossible. First the cost would be the typical 2-5 billion dollars. Secondly, it would need to undergo the trials process. Who would willingly invest billions in a substance whose efficacy is unknown and is available in natural form? Point #2: I note here that you are alive - which bears out the study results. Remember that it pertained to survival and not prevention. Once diagnosed, I would be delighted in the news that a very common food would quite likely assist in survival. Point #3: You must be alive to have complaints.

Posts.Title: Does curcumin reduce inflammation?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Magicmanjoejoe Hello all. Recently I went to the doctor for pain in the groin era. I went to a urologist and he almost dismissed it as nothing(much like my PCP) who said it was nothing. He almost dismissed it because of my age(I’m 26, turning 27 this year) and said it’s gas’s probably causing the pain. I don’t know what to think honestly but I’m scared at the possibly of prostate cancer since my symptoms may match. Am I right for being concerned? Bear with me, as I am analyzing your choice of words and actions. Several problems here. Are doctors only competent if they agree with you? What if they are right and you do not have cancer? Are you prepared to deal with that? I'm not a betting man, but I'll bet that anxiety will simply drive you to suspect some other sinister condition. PSA does not diagnose prostate cancer. I hope that you will have or did have a DRE, which is unneeded, but might give you some reassurance. I have noted that there is an extremely fine line between being "proactive" regarding health and suffering from health anxiety. Please ponder that. Next doctor visit, please mention that others think you may suffer from some form of anxiety, since 1 in 5 do. At your age, you deserve to live in peace.

Posts.Title: Heterogeneous irregular prostate with indentation of the base of the bladder

Posts.Content: Very sorry to hear this. Still, a clinical trial is an excellent opportunity. Though it was for lymphoma/transplant, I am now in my fourth clinical trial. Two for cancer and two for transplant rejection issues. One trial kept me in full response for 4 1/2 years, when I had been scheduled for palliative therapy. I hope here to encourage. Two relapses, one mutation into two sub-types, a third treatment-related bone marrow cancer, and we ran out of drugs to use. My prognosis was so abysmal that there is not a word to describe it. Yet, I have ten years into this. Since worry is negative and had no good purpose, better to make plans, no matter how sad those plans may seem. As I see it, it is better to have a plan which might not be needed than to be faced with a critical situation while lacking plans. If you can, turn that nervous worrying energy into positive planning. Research clinical trials, as even if he does not benefit, he will be helping those after him by advancing medical science. Give up worry. Don't give up hope.

Posts.Title: Is it time to worry?

Posts.Content: With soy being a known allergen, my only counsel is to watch for signs of sensitivity.

Posts.Title: Tbl-12

Posts.Content: As to loss, when I graduated from high school, we had the star athlete and all around good guy who did not even last that summer. Someone convinced him to shoot heroin and that was that. Loss is a part of our lives that we do not like to deal with, but must. As to the future; as to long range plans, I think that British economist John Maynard Keynes said it best: "In the long run, we're all dead." OK. As to cancer, President Reagan rather famously said "I don't have cancer. Something in me has cancer and the doctors are going to remove it." A different take on the subject, but it worked.

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: 0.01 is indistinguishable from 0.00. I believe that it is well within the margin of error in the testing procedure - and comparable results occur only if compared to the same type of test performed by the same laboratory.

Posts.Title: Am I a dead man walking? New member

Posts.Content: Too early to tell. The panic we can recognize. Keep in mind that someone survives every type of cancer. With some cancers, a lot survive. That is what we aim for. As to the type/stage/grade/location, you could be identical to the guy standing next to you - but his would not respond and yours would. Differences in our DNA at some level determine this.

DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.

Posts.Title: Am I a dead man walking? New member

Posts.Content: As to loss, when I graduated from high school, we had the star athlete and all around good guy who did not even last that summer. Someone convinced him to shoot heroin and that was that. Loss is a part of our lives that we do not like to deal with, but must. As to the future; as to long range plans, I think that British economist John Maynard Keynes said it best: "In the long run, we're all dead." OK. As to cancer, President Reagan rather famously said "I don't have cancer. Something in me has cancer and the doctors are going to remove it." A different take on the subject, but it worked.

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Too early to tell. The panic we can recognize. Keep in mind that someone survives every type of cancer. With some cancers, a lot survive. That is what we aim for. As to the type/stage/grade/location, you could be identical to the guy standing next to you - but his would not respond and yours would. Differences in our DNA at some level determine this.

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Too early to tell. The panic we can recognize. Keep in mind that someone survives every type of cancer. With some cancers, a lot survive. That is what we aim for. As to the type/stage/grade/location, you could be identical to the guy standing next to you - but his would not respond and yours would. Differences in our DNA at some level determine this.

Posts.Title: Am I a dead man walking? New member

Posts.Content: I note that statistics apply to populations rather than individuals. As well, any such calculator is a snapshot of this moment, and excludes future scientific or medical advances. Had I used such a calculator in 2008 it would likely have given me 6 months. Fortunately, I did not, and science put forth a new drug, which completely changed the picture.

Posts.Title: Calculator - Recurrence after curative options exhausted

Posts.Content: Very sorry to hear of all the difficulties. In such a traumatic tome as a cancer diagnosis or surgical treatment, many things can and do go wrong. Your husband's difficulties might be exceptional and unanticipated, or may be relatively normal. Yet, the treatment team normally provides contact information for such cases. I would not expect doctor to answer, but rather a nurse or practitioner, as that is the normal routing of such concerns. I know that, in our case, a lot of what we were told simply flew over our heads in the confusion and complication of the entire situation. Do they have an after-care team? Since you are the care-giver, I have taken the liberty of moving your post tot he prostate cancer forum, where it will probably receive helpful replies.

Posts.Title: What nobody told before surgery

Posts.Content: This is a single study and, in the grand scheme of things, is almost anecdotal in its findings regarding PCa. It was limited to 281 patients who had the most commonly occurring cancers: breast, colon, lung and prostate. From the abstract: "We identified 281 patients with nonmetastatic breast, prostate, lung, or colorectal cancer" My thinking is that the nature of localized prostate cancer skewed the numbers somewhat. It tends to advance slowly before becoming truly life-threatening - this point occurring perhaps near the end of the study. But, what happens thereafter? That infamous "hockeystick" graph may apply to the mortality rates of PCa, as it is not going to remain localized forever. Say you are diagnosed at age 45. Would you risk an unproven alternative claim for 10 years only to find out that, at age 55, you will be in a fight for your life? As a practical matter, try to find an insurance company that will even consider 'alternative medicine'. Last I checked, the alt sellers don't give it away.

Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine - Study Finds No Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: This is a single study and, in the grand scheme of things, is almost anecdotal in its findings regarding PCa. It was limited to 281 patients who had the most commonly occurring cancers: breast, colon, lung and prostate. From the abstract: "We identified 281 patients with nonmetastatic breast, prostate, lung, or colorectal cancer" My thinking is that the nature of localized prostate cancer skewed the numbers somewhat. It tends to advance slowly before becoming truly life-threatening - this point occurring perhaps near the end of the study. But, what happens thereafter? That infamous "hockeystick" graph may apply to the mortality rates of PCa, as it is not going to remain localized forever. Say you are diagnosed at age 45. Would you risk an unproven alternative claim for 10 years only to find out that, at age 55, you will be in a fight for your life? As a practical matter, try to find an insurance company that will even consider 'alternative medicine'. Last I checked, the alt sellers don't give it away.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Incontinence

Posts.Content: Many men with high PSA never develop cancer. Prostate cancer, as I recall, is often asymptomatic. That PSA reading "could" even be related to all of the inflammation/infection that has been in the area. And, we could be talking a chronic infection, since these obvious symptoms have occurred for several years. If your PSA reading had occurred say, during a routine physical exam (with no urinary symptoms), it would be perhaps more indicative of potential trouble. The DRE indicates nothing palpable, which should be a comfort. Please try to avoid over-thinking this, as very little is known at this point. I have moved this to the prostate forum, where it will receive much more attention.

Posts.Title: Scared to death

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ray61 What am I missing here? Everything I have read indicates a 2.1 PSA in a 41 year old is considered a normal read. Not even sure why this would rate a second test let alone the threat of a biopsy. Maybe one of the other guys can enlighten me. Ray Ray, you are exactly right. My bad for failing to check the charts first. Shaney5944 your PSA is normal. You might consider consulting with a different urologist. PSA can rise due to infection or inflammation in the area and you have certainly had that, but your PSA level is still normal. If this does not comfort you, tell doctor that you have anxiety over this issue. I am closing this thread now and hoping that you never have need of posting here in the future. However, if you do, we are here for support.

Posts.Content: Sorry to welcome you under these circumstances. I have moved this to the prostate cancer forum, since it is a specific diagnosis. Having said that, please be advised that naturopathy is NOT medicine - it is at most nutrition. If anything lowered your dad's PSA, it was the hormone therapy. The subsequent rise in PSA once again demonstrates that natural substances do not fight cancer, but only help nourish a body that is overwhelmed with cancer. My dad tried such and promptly died. There are many here with excellent advice and you will hear from them shortly.

Posts.Title: incision pain

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Ranger, the others are giving you pretty fair comments. This really is NOT a nasty forum. I keep hearing commercials on radio for a service called LifeLock, which is an identity protection program. At the first sign of someone attempting to use a client's identity (credit card, etc), it alerts the customer and stops the transaction if it is unauthorized. Part of the disclaimer of these commercials is, in paraphrase, "Of course, NOBODY can stop identity theft all the time, but we'll act on it as soon as it is discovered." The same thing applies to most things in life -- including this fine forum. I do not allow people to attack each other but, as with LifeLock, I cannot always catch them as they are clicking "post" on their comments. But I do act on it -- and stop it in its tracks -- as soon as I discover it. I tune into this forum multiple times each day and scan virtually every single post that is made for such behavior. That is why I stopped these particular attacks -- and then locked the thread -- so quickly. That is to ensure that this forum remains what is probably the friendliest PC forum in the world. Thus, we urge you to stick with us and not be pushed away from a couple of bad apples in a large barrel. Take care, Chuck ***Like***

Posts.Title: I'am outta here....

Posts.Content: My advice: Do not allow one or two insensitive members and their callous words to influence you. This is a public, world-wide forum - an internet crowd of people if you will. Someone, somewhere is likely to stand up and shout almost anything. What's worse is that male egos are involved. Cyber-chest bumping. That is the dross. Skim the dross off and look for the substance of the posts. Kindly note that the thread has been closed due to the specific reasons that you mention. Excepting myself, of all the forums I am on, this one is by far the best moderated.
Posts.Signature: 05/08-07/08 Tumor appears behind left ear. Followed by serial medical incompetence on the parts of PCP, veteran oncologist and pathologist (misdiagnosis via non-diagnosis). Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: I'am outta here....

Posts.Content: You sound anxious. That does not help. At this point, nothing is pointing to a malignancy. To continue to focus on cancer indicates, to me, a certain level of treatable anxiety. Best not to be freaked out about what is not cancer. If you cannot be, or are not comforted by the DRE and response to antibiotics, then do look into something like Cognitive Behavioral Therapy to calm your fears. You are intended to live in peace, not in fear.
Posts.Title: Possible Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear of your worries. What does dad think? After all, it's his life. Virtually all prostates enlarge - it is an extremely common, natural process. Have a read: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-...s/syc-20370087 Two key points: 1. The DRE was good. 2. The situation improved with antibiotics. It would be far more concerning if it did not improve with antibiotics. A re-test for PSA would be proper, but pre-test instructions must be followed for an accurate test. As well, the same methodology and testing lab must be used for the results to have any meaning.

Posts.Content: My advice: Do not allow one or two insensitive members and their callous words to influence you. This is a public, world-wide forum - an internet crowd of people if you will. Someone, somewhere is likely to stand up and shout almost anything. What's worse is that male egos are involved. Cyber-chest bumping. That is the dross. Skim the dross off and look for the substance of the posts. Kindly note that the thread has been closed due to the specific reasons that you mention. Excepting myself, of all the forums I am on, this one is by far the best moderated.

BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: 28 Year old and have most symptoms of PC

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Seems like all is okay again. Now for a nice quiet weekend. LOL One can always dream. The rude awakening was invented to restore reality.
Posts.Title: All the locked threads???

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Then I'm not sure of the reason for the Flomax or alternatives--they can have side effects. In any case, none of the meds discussed above are habit-forming. Quite right. Melatonin, Benadryl/other anti-histamines, Trazodone are all seemingly better choices than Flomax, as I see it. F.Y.I. for those who may not know, virtually all of the over-the-counter sleep aids are diphenhydramine hydrochloride - in other words, Benadryl anti-histamine.
Posts.Title: insomnia with flowmax, alternative?

Posts.Content: Lupron and Bicalutamide are not chemotherapy drugs. If I understand correctly (I'm a lymphoma guy), they are hormone antagonists, which have the ultimate effect of reducing the production of hormones which facilitate prostate cancer growth. They have side effects (as does aspirin), but I see no evidence that they interfere with the immune system, or directly attack human tissues, as most chemotherapy drugs do. Remember also that the doctors are not out to kill your father, but to save him by killing the cancer. They well know the dosages which are safe and appropriate, given your dad's overall health. Any adverse reaction he has can be controlled, or the drug reduced or eliminated, depending on how his treatment proceeds. As to chemotherapy worries, I was 10 years younger than your dad, but I received maximum doses of eight chemotherapy drugs in four months. I went on to receive 17 chemotherapy drugs total, and I am still alive, and happy to be so. The immediate concern with your dad is to kill or greatly slow down the cancer. And, if doctor is concerned, taking the treatment up a notch seems to be appropriate. Will it be easy? No, but cancer is harder.

Posts.Content: The only way to know what a smooth prostate feels like is to feel smooth prostates. Male or female, what's the dif? Women may actually have more sensitive fingers and may detect a smaller or more subtle abnormality.

Posts.Title: What's your thoughts on a female doing the DRE exam

Posts.Content: Aaron, the very first word in your thread title tells volumes. You are suffering from fear, anxiety - whatever you choose to call it. First, consult with a (different) doctor regarding the pain, then be absolutely certain to tell doctor of the fear and anxiety that is dominating your thoughts. No one has told you that you have anything wrong, let alone cancer. Do both of these things are you will once again have some peace of mind.

The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.

Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. Posts.Title: Vacuum Pumps

Posts.Content: This is merely anecdotal, but I was prescribed Trazodone for insomnia. It is primarily an anti-depressant and anti-anxiety drug, but also has the effect of producing sleep. However, I found also that it produces the same desired effect as Flomax, apparently causing some muscle relaxation. My hematologist described it as a "clean drug" - one with few disadvantages in that it may be stopped and started without tapers, and that seems to be easy for the body to metabolize and eliminate. Dosage makes quite a difference in my case, so one may have to experiment a bit to find the ideal balance of effects. Compared to many others it is also quite affordable, being a long established drug.
Posts.Signature: 05/08-07/08 Tumor appears behind left ear. Followed by serial medical incompetence on the parts of PCP, veteran oncologist and pathologist (misdiagnosis via non-diagnosis). Providential guidance to proper care at an NCI designated comprehensive cancer center. 07/08 Age 56 DX 1) Peripheral T-Cell Lymphoma-Not Otherwise Specified. Stage IV-B, >50 ("innumerable") tumors, bone marrow involvement. 08/08-12/08 Four cycles CHOEP14 + four cycles GND (Cyclofosfamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Etoposide, Prednisone & Gemcitabine, Navelbine, Doxil) 02/09 2) Relapse. 03/09-06/13 Clinical trial of Romidepsin > long-term study. NED for 64 twenty-eight day cycles, dose tapered. 07/13 3) Relapse, 4) Suspected Mutation. 08/13-02/14 Romidepsin increased, stopped for lack of response. Watch & Wait. 09/14 Relapse/Progression. Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer HIFU

Posts.Content: The web is saturated with all sorts of things. At first blush, this abstract sounds nonsensical since, if you deprive the body of sugar, basic nutrition, increase alkalinity and other fad methods, it also negatively impacts your immune system. Not a medical professional, but am wondering how that would help? While cancer cells are being malnourished, so are your healthy cells! It would be truly wonderful if fighting DNA mutations was that simple.

Posts.Title: Fasting and Caloric Restriction in Cancer Prevention and Treatment.

Posts.Content: 1. "Prognosis" is a statistical construct and applies only to patient populations. 2. It does not apply to any individual. 3. Someone not only survives each and every cancer, but thrives. 4. Aim to be that someone. Vastly different cancer(s), but in 2017 I was given a 99.5% chance of not surviving my various diagnoses. I chose not to listen.

Posts.Title: Prognosis, do you believe your doctor?

Posts.Content: Melatonin left me with a hangover - maybe my body was just slow to metabolize it. Trazodone's effectiveness seems proportionate to dosage. 50 mg knocks me out, whereas 25 mg allows me to sleep and actually wake up. But, I noted happily that flow was increased. So, a win-win there.

Posts.Title: insomnia with flowmax, alternative?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Then I'm not sure of the reason for the Flomax or alternatives--they can have side effects. In any case, none of the meds discussed above are habit-forming. Quite right. Melatonin, Benadryl/other anti-histamines, Trazodone are all seemingly better choices than Flomax, as I see it. F.Y.I. for those who may not know, virtually all of the over-the-counter sleep aids are diphenhydramine hydrochloride - in other words, Benadryl anti-histamine.
Posts.Title: insomnia with flowmax, alternative?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH $heeee!t! It's always something, eh? I'll check it out. Originally Posted by DjinTonic Seems that all is fixed. Thanks. Depending on the post count, it might be that the forum software was written to curtail spammers. Still, glitches do happen and they can be reported to the forum mod or any supermod.

The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. Posts.Content: Amen, Chuck! However, we don't want to put ourselves out of work, do we? Well, as long as you and I are around, there will be some work to do....

Posts.Title: What's your thoughts on a female doing the DRE exam

Posts.Content: Melatonin left me with a hangover - maybe my body was just slow to metabolize it. Trazodone's effectiveness seems proportionate to dosage. 50 mg knocks me out, whereas 25 mg allows me to sleep and actually wake up. But, I noted happily that flow was increased. So, a win-win there.

Posts.Title: small slow stream

Posts.Content: The only way to know what a smooth prostate feels like is to feel smooth prostates. Male or female, what's the dif? Women may actually have more sensitive fingers and may detect a smaller or more subtle abnormality.

Posts.Title: Not me

Posts.Content: I you are in any sort of systemic/chemotherapeutic treatment, ask doctor first! Why? Various natural substances affect the liver's production of certain enzymes - enzymes which are critical in metabolizing the chemotherapy drugs. For example citrus fruits contain hydroxybergamottin, which reduces the liver's production of an enzyme known as CYP3A4. Grapefruit has a substantial amount of this, so must be avoided in those receiving certain drugs.

Posts.Title: Saw Palmetto

Posts.Content: If the cancer was somehow 100% confined to the prostate, and the prostate was 100% removed, there should be very little chance of recurrence - nothing being impossible in the absolute sense. A single cancer cell that has migrated to some other area of your body cannot be eradicated if it cannot be found. There is reason to believe that mutated, even malignant cells may go into a dormant state, only to be awakened by some unknown factor in the future. In this life, we never have any assurance that we are "cancer free." No responsible person (neighbor, friend, doctor, scientist etc.) would tell you that. We can be assured only that there is no evidence of cancer (NED). At current levels of technology, the threshold of detection is on the order of one million cancer cells. In one sense, we are only "cured" of cancer if we expire of some other cause. Now, all of this, taken somewhat improperly, may lead us to a state of insecurity, but it does have one great advantage: that of reminding us daily of the blessing which each day of life is. As to PSA, testing must be done using the same protocol and by the same lab to have a hope of being comparable. Yet even then there are numerous variables. For all I know, there may be a substance in the body that is not PSA, but is similar enough to provoke an occasional false positive. While this may not be satisfying, the bottom line as I see it is to live each day and love each day - not a single one is guaranteed to any of us.

Posts.Title: A simple thought about <.1 ng/ml versus 0.0

Posts.Content: Aaron, the very first word in your thread title tells volumes. You are suffering from fear, anxiety - whatever you choose to call it. First, consult with a (different) doctor regarding the pain, then be absolutely certain to tell doctor of the fear and anxiety that is dominating your thoughts. No one has told you that you have anything wrong, let alone cancer. Do both of these things are you will once again have some peace of mind.

Posts.Title: Terrified That I Have Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: These are always good signs that progress is being made. There is more hope today than at any time in human history. Still, we should temper our enthusiasm just a bit, and patiently wait, as it is a huge leap from mouse to man. Every single anticipated "miracle" drug that we cannot buy failed to make that leap. As well, the diversity of caner variations - even within a single type, is incredible, being based on our unique DNAs. For this very reason, there is no one treatment with a 100% response rate. Still, research is unrelenting, a good match for the nature of cancer. This will be one to watch with interest.

Visible cervical nodes appear within 4 days of being checked clear. 10/06/14 One cycle Belinostat. Discontinued to enter second clinical trial. 10/25/14 Clinical trial of Alisertib/Failed - Progression. 01/12/15 Belinostat resumed/Failed - Progression. 02/23/15 02/24/15 Pralatrexate/Failed - Progression. 04/17/15 04/15 Genomic profiling reveals mutation into PTCL-NOS + AngioImmunoblastic T-Cell Lymphoma. Stage IV-B a second time. Two dozen tumors + small intestine (Ileum) involvement. 04/22/15 TEC (Bendamustine, Etoposide, Carboplatin). Full response in two cycles. PET/CT both clear. Third cycle followed. 06/15-07/15 Transplant preparation (X-rays, spinal taps, BMB, blood test, MUGA scan, lung function, CMV screening, C-Diff testing etc. etc. etc.) Intrathecal Methotrexate during spinal tap. BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
Posts.Title: Cancer Cure ?

Posts.Content: Not a prostate patient, but a truism of cancer therapy is: You always have a choice. Making once choice often eliminates the other choices. Having made the choice there is often no going back. Once you have made it, there is no way of knowing if it was indeed the best choice. Sorry to say, but cancer, being part of life itself, is just as unpredictable. You can make an informed decision, after study of the studies and statistics, but still have no guarantee of success. We all wish it was more clear than this.

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice?

Posts.Content: Lupron and Bicalutamide are not chemotherapy drugs. If I understand correctly (I'm a lymphoma guy), they are hormone antagonists, which have the ultimate effect of reducing the production of hormones which facilitate prostate cancer growth. They have side effects (as does aspirin), but I see no evidence that they interfere with the immune system, or directly attack human tissues, as most chemotherapy drugs do. Remember also that the doctors are not out to kill your father, but to save him by killing the cancer. They well know the dosages which are safe and appropriate, given your dad's overall health. Any adverse reaction he has can be controlled, or the drug reduced or eliminated, depending on how his treatment proceeds. As to chemotherapy worries, I was 10 years younger than your dad, but I received maximum doses of eight chemotherapy drugs in four months. I went on to receive 17 chemotherapy drugs total, and I am still alive, and happy to be so. The immediate concern with your dad is to kill or greatly slow down the cancer. And, if doctor is concerned, taking the treatment up a notch seems to be appropriate. Will it be easy? No, but cancer is harder.

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Therapy in Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: The only way to know what a smooth prostate feels like is to feel smooth prostates. Male or female, what's the dif? Women may actually have more sensitive fingers and may detect a smaller or more subtle abnormality.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer HIFU

Posts.Content: 1. "Prognosis" is a statistical construct and applies only to patient populations. 2. It does not apply to any individual. 3. Someone not only survives each and every cancer, but thrives. 4. Aim to be that someone. Vastly different cancer(s), but in 2017 I was given a 99.5% chance of not surviving my various diagnoses. I chose not to listen.

BMB reveals 5) 26% blast cells of 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome MDS), a bone marrow cancer and precursor to Acute Myeloid Leukemia. 07/11-12/15 Cyclofosfamide + Fludarabine conditioning regimen. 07/16/15 Total Body Irradiation. 07/17/15 Moderate intensity Haploidentical Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant receiving my son's peripheral blood stem cells. 07/21-22/15 Triple dose Cyclofosfamide + Mesna, followed by immunosuppressants Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. 07/23-08/03/15 Marrow producing zero blood cells. Fever. Hospitalized two weeks. 08/04/15 Engraftment occurs, and blood cells are measurable - released from hospital. 08/13/15 Day 26 - Marrow is 100% donor cells. Platelets climbing steadily, red cells follow. 09/21/15 Acute skin Graft versus Host Disease arrives. DEXA scan reveals Osteoporosis. 09/26/-11/03/15 Prednisone to control skin GvHD. 11/2015 Acute GvHD re-classified to Chronic Graft versus Host Disease. 05/2016 Tacrolimus stopped. Prednisone from 30-90mg daily tried. Sirolimus begun. Narrow-band UV-B therapy started, but discontinued for lack of response. One treatment of P-UVAreceived, but halted due to medication reaction. 09/16/16 Three skin punch biopsies. 11/04/16 GvHD clinical trial of Ofatumumab (Arzerra) + Prednisone + Methylprednisolone begun. 12/16 Type II Diabetes, Hypertension - both treatment-related. 05/17 Extracorporeal Photopheresis (ECP) begun in attempt to control chronic Graft-versus-Host-Disease (cGvHD. 8 year old Power Port removed and replaced with Vortex (Smart) Port for ECP. 05/2017 Chronic anemia (low hematocrit). Chronic kidney disease. Cataracts from radiation and steroids. 06/17 Trying various antibiotics in a search for tolerable prophylaxis. 08/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of 2% cells with 20q Deletion Myelodysplastic Syndrome, considered to be Minimum Residual Disease. 12/17 Bone marrow biopsy reveals no abnormalities in the marrow - MDS eradicated. The steroid taper continues. 01/18 Consented for Kadmon clinical trial. 03/18 Began 400mg daily of KD025, a rho-Associated Coiled-coil Kinase 2 Inhibitor (ROCK2). 09/18 Due to refractory GvHD, Extracorporeal Photopheresis halted after 15 months ue to lack of additional benefit. 10/18 I was withdrawn from the Kadmon KD025 clinical trial due to increasing fatigue/lack of benefit. 11/18 Began therapy with Ruxolitinib (Jakafi), a JAK 1&2 inhibitor class drug. Started at half-dose due to concerns with drug interactions. To date: 1 cancer, relapse, second relapse/mutation into 2 cancers, then 3 cancers simultaneously, 20 chemotherapy/GVHD drugs in 11 regimens (4 of them at least twice), 5 salvage regimens, 4 clinical trials, 5 post-transplant immuno-suppressant/modulatory drugs, the equivalent of 1,000 years of background radiation from 40+ CT series scans and about 24 PET scans. Both lymphoid and myeloid malignancies lend a certain symmetry to the hematological journey. Believing in the redemptive value of suffering makes all the difference.
